title: There's a role for the Future Fund in a government super fund
text:
The Commonwealth Superannuation Corporation already has almost $50 billion under management - about one-quarter of AustralianSuper's assets - for tens of thousands of public servant members.

If the government opted for a public super fund for private sector workers the CSC would be a potential vehicle to deal with fund members.

Under Costello’s loose plan, the Future Fund would play a wholesale support role - such as helping select the world’s best investment managers, advising on asset allocation and perhaps negotiating fund manager fees.

Costello, the country's longest-serving treasurer, is chairman of Nine, owner of The Australian Financial Review.

The government is not actively considering a public super fund, but nor has it been taken completely off the table.

More due consideration will come in coming months as Frydenberg tackles how to fix the shoddy $595 billion default superannuation system for workers who don't select a fund.

Former treasurer Peter Costello is now chairman of the $163 billion Future Fund. Eamon Gallagher

The Productivity Commission's three-year probe into the efficiency and competitiveness of the superannuation system concluded that consumers could gain $3.8 billion a year by addressing unintended multiple accounts and entrenched underperforming funds.

Advertisement

Undoubtedly, part of the attraction to a public default super fund to some political conservatives, such as Costello and Liberal backbencher Tim Wilson, is to negate the meteoric rise of union-aligned industry super funds.

Industry funds have outperformed for-profit retail funds and are less financially conflicted in maximising returns for members.

Nevertheless, there are legitimate public policy and investment arguments for a sovereign fund to manage super, backed by non-partisans such as businessman John Wylie (who knows super architect Paul Keating from working together at Lazard), index pioneer Graham Tuckwell and former adviser to Labor treasurer John Dawkins, economist Nicholas Gruen.

In a system where the government mandates almost 10 per cent of people’s wages be deferred and clipped by money managers, and there is a chronic underperformance and fee-gouging by a large minority of funds, a low-fee public default fund is worthy of considering.

The investment profile, return targets, time horizons and liquidity requirements for a public super fund would be different to the strong-performing $163 billion Future Fund.

The money would not be lumped into the same pool - another ill-informed criticism by the super industry.

Rather than arguing a public fund would be incapable of handling super, the super industry would be better served by pointing to the same fiscal risks as the Productivity Commission.

The commission said the biggest risk of a government "monopoly" fund was that in the event of poor performance there could be significant political pressure on the government to "top up" returns for members and taxpayers could be put at risk.

Then again, with the super juggernaut close to $3 trillion and set to hit $5 trillion by 2030, some argue there is already an implicit guarantee on our super funds just like the big banks.
description: If super funds run by former politicians and union officials are capable of handling the administration of super, then surely it is not beyond the capability of a government fund.
